paths.title: DNA Fundamentals
paths.description: Learn core genetic concepts through visual programming: codon redundancy, mutation types, and reading frames.
learningObjectives: Understand codon structure and triplet reading frames
Recognize silent mutations and genetic redundancy
Distinguish missense, nonsense, and frameshift mutations

steps.title: Hello Genome
steps.narrative: Every genome begins with ATG (START) and ends with a stop codon (TAA/TAG/TGA). This simple program draws a single circle, showing the basic triplet structure of genetic code.
steps.keyTakeaway: Codons are 3-letter instructions, like DNA triplets encoding amino acids.
steps.tryIt: Change the PUSH value (AAT → AAC) and observe the radius change.

steps.title: Silent Mutations
steps.narrative: Multiple codons can encode the same instruction. GGA and GGC both mean CIRCLE - this is genetic redundancy, just like how multiple DNA codons encode the same amino acid.
steps.keyTakeaway: Silent mutations change the sequence but not the output (genotype ≠ phenotype).
steps.tryIt: Use the 'Silent' mutation button in playground to see identical outputs.

steps.title: Missense Mutations
steps.narrative: When GGA (CIRCLE) mutates to CCA (RECT), the shape changes - a missense mutation. The program still runs, but the phenotype is different.
steps.keyTakeaway: Missense mutations substitute one function for another, changing the result.
steps.tryIt: Change GGA → CCA and observe shape transformation.

steps.title: Nonsense Mutations
steps.narrative: When a drawing instruction mutates to TAA (STOP), execution halts early. This is like a nonsense mutation creating a premature stop codon in DNA.
steps.keyTakeaway: Nonsense mutations cause early termination, producing incomplete outputs.
steps.tryIt: Change any instruction to TAA and watch the output truncate.

steps.title: Frameshift Mutations
steps.narrative: Inserting or deleting a single base shifts the reading frame, scrambling all downstream codons. The effect is catastrophic - like reading 'THE CAT ATE' as 'TH ECA TAT E'.
steps.keyTakeaway: Frameshifts affect all subsequent instructions, causing dramatic phenotype changes.
steps.tryIt: Delete one letter and use the linter to see frame violations.

steps.title: Mutation Comparison
steps.narrative: With multiple shapes, you can compare mutation impacts. Try each type and use the DiffViewer to see side-by-side comparisons.
steps.keyTakeaway: Different mutations have predictable, characteristic effects on complex genomes.
steps.tryIt: Apply each mutation type and observe visual differences in the comparison panel.

paths.title: Visual Programming Journey
paths.description: Master CodonCanvas programming from basic shapes to complex compositions using transforms, state management, and loops.
learningObjectives: Use drawing primitives (CIRCLE, RECT, LINE, TRIANGLE)
Create loops and patterns with LOOP opcode

steps.title: Basic Shapes
steps.narrative: Start with the simplest program: PUSH a value, draw a CIRCLE. All visual programs build from these primitive shapes.
steps.keyTakeaway: Stack-based VM: push values, then consume them with drawing operations.
steps.tryIt: Try other shapes: change GGA (CIRCLE) to CCA (RECT) or GCA (TRIANGLE).

steps.title: Color & Position
steps.narrative: TRANSLATE moves your drawing position, COLOR (TT* family) changes hue/saturation/lightness. Combine them to create colorful compositions.
steps.keyTakeaway: Transforms modify the drawing context for all subsequent operations.
steps.tryIt: Adjust COLOR values (hue 0-360, saturation/lightness 0-100).

steps.title: Rotation
steps.narrative: ROTATE changes the drawing direction. When combined with LINE, you can create angled patterns and radial designs.
steps.keyTakeaway: Rotation accumulates - each ROTATE adds to the current angle.
steps.tryIt: Change rotation degrees and observe directional changes.

steps.title: State Management
steps.narrative: Save your current position/rotation/color, draw something, then restore. This enables branching and nested compositions without losing your place.
steps.keyTakeaway: State stack allows non-destructive exploration - save, experiment, restore.
steps.tryIt: Add SAVE_STATE before a transform, RESTORE_STATE after to see state preservation.

steps.title: Repetition with LOOP
steps.narrative: LOOP repeats the next N instructions M times. Combine with ROTATE for radial patterns, TRANSLATE for grids, or both for spirals.
steps.keyTakeaway: LOOP + transforms = powerful pattern generation with minimal code.
steps.tryIt: Change LOOP iteration count or nested instructions to create variations.

steps.title: Complex Composition
steps.narrative: Advanced compositions use all techniques: nested loops, state management, color gradients, and multiple layers. Study how they combine.
steps.keyTakeaway: Mastery comes from combining primitives in creative ways.
steps.tryIt: Modify one aspect at a time to understand how components interact.

paths.title: Nature's Algorithms
paths.description: Explore how biological patterns emerge from simple algorithmic rules: fractals, spirals, cellular structures, and growth patterns.
learningObjectives: Recognize fractal patterns in nature (trees, neurons, blood vessels)
Understand phyllotaxis and the golden angle (137.5°)
See how cell division creates hierarchical structures
Connect algorithmic patterns to biological forms

steps.title: Fractal Branching
steps.narrative: Trees, neurons, and blood vessels all use fractal branching. Each branch splits into smaller branches following the same rule - recursion in nature.
steps.keyTakeaway: Complex biological structures emerge from simple recursive algorithms.
steps.tryIt: Adjust branch angles or scaling factors to see different tree morphologies.

steps.title: Golden Angle Spirals
steps.narrative: Sunflower seeds arrange at 137.5° intervals (the golden angle). This creates optimal packing spirals - Fibonacci numbers emerge naturally from this simple rule.
steps.keyTakeaway: Mathematical constants (golden ratio) appear in biological growth patterns.
steps.tryIt: Change the rotation angle from 137.5° to see spiral patterns degrade.

steps.title: Cell Division
steps.narrative: One cell becomes two, two become four. Cell division creates hierarchical family trees - every cell has a parent, grandparent, and so on.
steps.keyTakeaway: Exponential growth and cellular lineage visualized through nested structure.
steps.tryIt: Add more division stages to see population growth accelerate.

steps.title: Hexagonal Packing
steps.narrative: Bees build hexagonal cells because hexagons tile perfectly with minimal material. This is optimal packing - mathematics solving biological problems.
steps.keyTakeaway: Nature optimizes: hexagons provide maximum storage with minimum wax.
steps.tryIt: Try squares or triangles instead - notice wasted space or structural weakness.

steps.title: DNA Double Helix
steps.narrative: DNA's double helix has two complementary strands. The helical structure emerges from base pairing constraints - form follows function.
steps.keyTakeaway: Molecular structures reflect chemical constraints - complementary pairing creates helical geometry.
steps.tryIt: Adjust strand spacing or wave frequency to visualize structural variations.

steps.title: Neural Networks
steps.narrative: Neurons collect inputs (dendrites), process signals (soma), and send outputs (axon). This is biological computation - input, process, output.
steps.keyTakeaway: Biological networks process information through structure: branching inputs, central processing, output distribution.
steps.tryIt: Modify dendrite count or axon length to see network topology changes.

paths.title: Mathematical Beauty
paths.description: Discover mathematical patterns through code: Fibonacci spirals, fractals, parametric curves, and the golden ratio in visual form.
learningObjectives: Visualize Fibonacci numbers and the golden ratio
Generate parametric curves and mathematical roses
Understand how arithmetic operations enable complex patterns

steps.title: Fibonacci Spiral
steps.narrative: Fibonacci numbers (1,1,2,3,5,8...) approximate the golden ratio φ. Stack these as squares and trace their corners to create the iconic spiral.
steps.keyTakeaway: Fibonacci sequence converges to φ (1.618...), visible in spiral growth rates.
steps.tryIt: Observe how each square's size relates to previous two (F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2)).

steps.title: Golden Ratio φ
steps.narrative: φ = 1.618... appears throughout nature and art. Divide a line segment in golden ratio: the ratio of parts equals the ratio of whole to larger part.
steps.keyTakeaway: Golden ratio is self-similar: φ/1 = (φ+1)/φ, a recursive proportion.
steps.tryIt: Measure segment ratios to verify golden proportion (should be ~1.618).

steps.title: Rose Curves
steps.narrative: Rose curves use trigonometric functions: r = cos(kθ). Different k values create different petal counts - mathematics defining organic forms.
steps.keyTakeaway: Parametric equations (r, θ) create complex curves from simple trigonometric relationships.
steps.tryIt: Modify k value to change petal count (k=3 gives 3 petals, k=5 gives 5).

steps.title: Sierpiński Triangle
steps.narrative: Sierpiński triangle is infinitely self-similar: zoom in, and you see the same pattern. Each triangle contains three smaller copies of itself.
steps.keyTakeaway: Fractals exhibit self-similarity at all scales - the part resembles the whole.
steps.tryIt: Increase recursion depth to see finer detail emerge.

steps.title: Ulam Prime Spiral
steps.narrative: Arrange integers in a spiral, highlight primes. Surprisingly, primes cluster along diagonal lines - revealing hidden structure in their distribution.
steps.keyTakeaway: Visual patterns reveal mathematical relationships - primes aren't random, they have structure.
steps.tryIt: Extend the spiral to see more diagonal prime clusters emerge.

steps.title: Binary Tree Fractal
steps.narrative: Each branch splits into two smaller branches at fixed angles. Infinite recursion creates fractal complexity from a simple branching rule.
steps.keyTakeaway: Recursion + scaling = fractal dimension, complexity from simplicity.
steps.tryIt: Adjust branch angle or scale factor to create different fractal trees.
